audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the topic of answering the internet's most searched questions about "architects and architecture," setting a conversational and informative tone. He explains the methodology: searching on Google and answering the top results, using the example of "do architects blank." He expresses readiness to begin by saying "let us proceed shall we?". Then he presents the first query: "do architects do math?"

The audio begins with a single male speaker in a casual, conversational tone, emphasizing that architects do math and that it's a "practicable and masterable skill." He questions whether "masterable" is a word. He proceeds to the next question about the skill of drawing.

The clip begins with speech from a male speaker explaining that architects need to be good at drawing, mentioning architecture school and drawing subjects. The speaker then transitions to the topic of architects' salary, posing it as a "Schr√∂dinger's cat" question with a "yes or no" answer. He continues to elaborate that some architects earn a lot, while others do not, comparing the high-earning architects to A-list actors like Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, Tom Cruise, and Brad Pitt, whom he calls "starchitects". He further shares that other architects, like himself, simply "earn an honest living". The speaker then finishes by posing the next question of, "do architects and engineers work together?", indicating a continuation in a question-and-answer format.

The clip begins with a single male speaker who introduces a "very controversial question" regarding architects and engineers. He mentions the misconception that they dislike each other, stating that "architects love engineers" but maybe not vice versa. He answers the question in the affirmative, saying that "architects and engineers work together" and should collaborate. He proceeds to another question about architects traveling, noting he doesn't travel much due to local projects but knows others who have projects around the country. The speaker then moves on to the next phrase for search.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing architects. He starts by answering the question "Can architects be rich?" with a brief affirmative, clarifying that it depends on the definition of rich. Next, he addresses whether architects can have tattoos, suggesting there's no reason why not, as perceptions of tattoos are changing. He humorously imagines a future with heavily tattooed architects. Then, he shifts the topic to structural drawings, inquiring, "Can architects sign structural drawings?". The speaking tone is conversational and lighthearted.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker firmly stating "No, architects cannot sign structural drawings," explaining the role of structural engineers in signing their own designs. The speaker then transitions to the topic of interior design, noting that architects were once allowed to engage in it in the Philippines, but a recent law now prevents them from doing so. Switching to the topic of working from home, he confidently states that "Absolutely," architects can work from home, describing his own routine of site visits followed by detailed work at home. Finally, the audio clip poses the question, "Can architects advertise?" in a neutral tone.

The clip starts with a single male speaker discussing the code of ethics for architects in the Philippines, specifically noting the restriction on advertising in traditional media like television and newspapers. He then transitions to discussing the gray area created by social media, where architects post their work online, raising the question of whether this constitutes advertising. The speaker's tone is conversational and informative. The clip ends abruptly with the query, "Are architects...blank?" followed by the assertion, "Are architects rich? Some are rich." and finally someone else simply saying "I am."

The clip starts with an informative narration about the demand for architects, noting their scarcity in the Philippines but popularity in developing countries like Singapore and Dubai. The speaker notes that people may perceive architects as "a luxury profession." The clip closes with an exclamation of agreement. Only a single male speaker is present in the audio.

The clip features a single male speaker addressing the questions of whether architects are artists and engineers, expressing the opinion that they are indeed engineers, shortened simply to "architects". His tone is casual and conversational, with a touch of humor. There's a brief chuckle as he contemplates whether architects are happy. The audio is clean, without music or background noise to compete with the speaker's voice.

The audio begins with a male speaker stating he is "a happy architect", but some of his batchmates are stressed. He goes on to ponder the question of why architects wear black, stating that he wears black because it suits him and hides ink stains. He then states that there are upsides to wearing black shirts but otherwise it is a personal preference. He moves on to the question of why architects need a license.

The audio begins with a male speaker stating that one doesn't need a license in general, but to become an architect, "you need an architectural license." He hopes this makes sense and proceeds to discuss why architects make models. He personally makes them to present "a physical representation of my design" to the client, especially when they struggle to understand computer renderings. Otherwise, he avoids scale models, mentioning they are costly and jokingly states, "I actually need all of my fingers" due to near cutting mishaps. The clip finishes with him asking why architects do a specific thing.

A man speaks in an informative tone, explaining why architects use copper roofs, stating "copper roofs probably look good". He goes on to explain why architects use blueprints, but explains that architects now use normal print outs because blueprinting is an old way of photocopying architectural plans, and it involves a ton of harmful chemicals. He mentions that the smell is similar to a public toilet, and adds that because large format printers have gone down in price, blueprinting is obsolete.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing line types in architecture, explaining their use in differentiating aspects of drawings and providing an example with dotted lines. The speaker then transitions into why architects sketch, stating that he sketches to come up with ideas.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining his artistic process. He states he does "a bunch of sketches," because it takes "little to no effort" and is "enjoyable," ultimately leading to a good design which he will "finalize into an actual drawing." There are no discernable background noises or music.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker asking, "How do architects?" then continues, "How do architects earn money?" He explains that architects earn money by getting clients, leading to the next question, "How do architects get clients?" The speaker explains that architects cannot advertise, so they rely on word of mouth. However, he adds that now social media provides an avenue to showcase work and get clients through the new media.

The clip features a male speaker explaining how architects design houses. He describes it as a complex process involving sketching, columns, and floor plans, noting that each architect has a unique approach. The speaker then humorously concludes that architects design houses "with our big brains." Immediately after, sounds that might indicate a silly or comical reaction come from the same speaker.

The clip begins with a question about architects and engineers working together, spoken in an inquisitive, neutral tone by one person. The speaker transitions to a descriptive, explanatory tone, outlining the collaborative process of architectural and structural design. The speaker explains sending the architectural design to engineers for structural analysis, and then receiving a structural design in return, highlighting the "back and forth process."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker posing a question. Another male speaker replies, his tone informative as he explains how architects charge, mentioning a percentage of the project cost in the Philippines.

The clip begins with one male speaker confidently discussing the compensation of architects, stating a calculation based on a project's cost. He then transitions to asking, in a questioning tone, "What do architects..." and provides brief answers about their roles, attire, and major in school.  He resumes the conversation by describing typical daily tasks and work attire, elaborating on varying dress code expectations within architectural firms.

The clip features a male speaker with a casual, slightly exaggerated tone discussing a hypothetical scenario where architects dress professionally for client visits, noting his preference for t-shirts at work due to not meeting clients. He wraps up by summarizing a journey into the "wide world of the interwebs," thanking listeners, and promising a future video. The clip concludes with him saying "flying peace" followed by a burp.
